Questions.QuestionString: 14. A spar web will take loads in. (Level 1)
15. Wing bending and shear loads are taken by. (Level 1)
16. A cantilever wing is a. (Level 1)
Answers: B. top wing of a biplane.

Questions.QuestionString: 17. On a mono-spar wing, what gives the wing its profile contour?. (Level 1)
Answers: B. The position of the spars.

19. The final coat of sealing in a integral fuel tank is called. (Level 1)
20. The principle load bearing members of the wing are. (Level 1)

22. The web of an 'I' beam takes mainly which type of load?. (Level 1)
23. Prior to aluminium alloy bonding, we use. (Level 1)
24. The term 'empennage' incorporates. (Level 1)
25. The four main structural items making up a horizontal stabiliser are. (Level 1)
Answers: A. spar, rib, bulkheads, skin panels.
B. spar, rib, stringers, skin panels.
C. spar, rib, longerons, skin panels.

Questions.QuestionString:
26. The direction of travel of an electrically operated variable incidence tailplane is
determined by. (Level 1)
Answers: C. direction of rotation of the electric motor.

Questions.QuestionString: 27. The fin helps to give. (Level 1)
Answers: A. directional stability about the normal axis.
B. longitudinal stability about the normal axis.
C. directional stability about the longitudinal axis.

Questions.QuestionString: 28. Which of the following are primary control surfaces?. (Level 1)
29. The outboard ailerons on some large aircraft. (Level 1)
Answers: A. are isolated at low speeds.
B. are isolated to improve sensitivity.
C. are isolated at high speeds.

Questions.QuestionString: 30. What is attached to the rear of the vertical stabilizer?. (Level 1)
31. Aerodynamic balance is used to. (Level 1)
Answers: A. make the flying controls easier to move.
B. prevent flutter of the flying controls.
C. reduce the control load to zero.

Questions.QuestionString: 32. A control surface is mass balanced by. (Level 1)
Answers: A. the attachment of weights acting forward of the hinge line.
B. the attachment of weights acting on the hinge line.

Questions.QuestionString: 33. The purpose of anti-balance tabs is to. (Level 1)
Answers: C. give more feel to the control column.

Questions.QuestionString: 34. In semi-monocoque construction, compression loads are taken by. (Level 1)
35. An elevator controls the aircraft motion in. (Level 1)
36. Jet engines are usually mounted by. (Level 1)
Answers: B. forged mounts and bolted to aircraft forged structure.

Questions.QuestionString: 37. A pylon structural member supports the. (Level 1)
38. The purpose of a primer is to. (Level 2)
Answers: A. provide shiny surface for the topcoat.
B. provide flexible surface for the top coat.
C. help bonding of the topcoat.

Questions.QuestionString:
39. Which of the following statements is correct, in relation to PLI washers used in critical
bolted joints?. (Level 2)
Answers: A. PLI washers can be affected by thread or nut friction or by lubrication.
B. PLI washers can only be used with self locking nuts and the washers should be used once.
C. PLI washers can be used more than once, providing they are used in critical bolted joints.

Questions.QuestionString:
40. When carrying out a symmetry check on a large aircraft, what method of measurement
is normally used?. (Level 2)
Answers: C. Steel tape and spring balance.

Questions.QuestionString: 41. To remove a rivet. (Level 2)
Answers:
A. drill the head with a drill bit slightly smaller than the rivet shank, chisel off the rivet head,
and remove the shank with a metal punch.
B. chisel off the rivet head, and remove the shank with a metal punch.

C. drill the head with a drill bit the same size as the rivet shank, chisel off the rivet head, and
remove the shank with a metal punch.

Questions.QuestionString: 42. Battery trays are. (Level 2)
Answers: A. absorbent to soak up electrolyte.
C. metal with PVC coating and anti corrosive paint.

Questions.QuestionString: 43. The primary purpose of sealant in use in pressurised aircraft is. (Level 2)
44. When installing a 'Hi-lock' bolt, it is necessary to. (Level 2)
Answers: A. simply fit the bolt as they are prelubricated.
C. lubricate the shank and threads.

Questions.QuestionString: 45. Most large transport aircraft skins are. (Level 1)
46. Sealant or levelling compound is installed during structure repair:. (Level 2)
Answers: A. according to AMM and SRM chapter 51.
C. according to separate manufacturer's documentations such as BAC.

Questions.QuestionString: 47. Dissimilar metal fusion bonding is best for. (Level 2)
48. The ideal conditions for paint spraying an aircraft are. (Level 2)

49. When both sides of a structural repair are not easily reached, which type of fastener
would you use?. (Level 2)
50. With regard to extraneous spilt fluids. (Level 2)
Answers: A. they may be harmful to the aircraft structure.
B. they should only be cleaned up if they are on the external surface of the aircraft.
C. they can be ignored, they provide extra protection.

Questions.QuestionString: 51. What is the normal form of construction of a spar?. (Level 2)
Answers: A. Two webs separated by a boom.
B. One boom mounted under a web.
C. Two booms separated by a web.

Questions.QuestionString: 52. A crack stopper is fitted. (Level 2)
Answers: A. before a crack starts, to prevent its initiation.
B. before a crack starts, to slow its rate of propagation.
C. after a crack starts, to slow its rate of propagation.

Questions.QuestionString: 53. Which of the following should be accomplished before jacking an aircraft?. (Level 2)
Answers: A. Install critical stress panels or plates.
B. Determine the fuel tanks are empty.

Questions.QuestionString: 54. One of the advantages of the semi-monocoque construction is that it. (Level 2)
Answers: C. takes all the loads in the skin.

Questions.QuestionString: 55. Intercostals are. (Level 2)
Answers: A. vertical struts joining the upper and lower wings of a biplane.
B. compression ribs in cantilever wings.
C. longitudinal fuselage members attached at each end to adjacent frames.

Questions.QuestionString: 56. What opposes buckling in a semi-monocoque structure?. (Level 1)
57. Joints that are designed to stop the propagation of cracks are known as. (Level 2)
58. An overweight landing is one in which the aircraft has. (Level 2)
Answers: A. too much kinetic energy on landing.
B. a missed placed centre of gravity on landing.
C. an excessive fuel load on take-off.

Questions.QuestionString: 59. Symmetry checks should be carried out. (Level 2)
Answers: A. in the hangar with the aircraft on its wheels.
B. on the ramp with the aircraft on its wheels.
C. in the hanger with the aircraft on jacks.

Questions.QuestionString: 60. The purpose of a wash primer and primer is to. (Level 2)
Answers: B. provide a flexible surface for top-coat.
C. provide more aerodynamic finish for top-coat.

Questions.QuestionString: 61. Dents are generally not permitted in a tubular member. (Level 2)
Answers: A. if they are located in the end thirds of the length of the member.
B. if the major axis of the dent is parallel to the tube axis irrespective of the location.
C. if they are located in the middle third of the length of the member.

Questions.QuestionString: 62. An aspect ratio of 8 could mean. (Level 2)
Answers: A. span 64 ft., mean chord 8 ft.
B. span squared 64 ft., chord 8 ft.
C. mean chord 64 ft., span 8 ft.

Questions.QuestionString: 63. A wing's leading edge would have provisions and linkages for slats and. (Level 2)
64. The mid-spar is fitted in large aircraft to. (Level 2)
Answers: A. support fitting the engine mount & landing gear mount.
B. assist the main spar with operational loads.

Questions.QuestionString: 65. One purpose of a rib is to. (Level 2)
Answers: A. support the bending loads on a fuselage.
B. form the main lateral member in an aerofoil.
C. maintain the correct contour of an aerofoils covering.

Questions.QuestionString: 66. What is a cantilever wing?. (Level 2)
Answers: A. One that folds for access to limited space.
B. One that has external supporting struts.
C. One that has no external supporting struts.

Questions.QuestionString: 67. In a monocoque structure, which component carries the majority of the loads?. (Level 1)
68. A spar is tapered from root to tip because. (Level 2)
Answers: A. shear forces are greatest at the root.
B. bending moment is greatest at the root.
C. centre of lift occurs close to the root.

Questions.QuestionString: 69. A spar web is. (Level 2)
Answers: A. a member between the spar and wing/fuselage connection.
B. an area between two spar caps.

Questions.QuestionString:
70. To correct for nose heaviness on an aircraft fitted with a variable incidence tailplane,
the incidence of the tailplane would be. (Level 2)
Answers: A. decreased, which is done by lowering the leading edge.
B. decreased, which is done by lowering the trailing edge.
C. increased, which is done by lowering the leading edge.

Questions.QuestionString: 71. An upward elevator deflection on the reverse camber tailplane. (Level 2)
Answers: A. may increase or decrease download depending upon the aircraft C of G position.

Questions.QuestionString: 72. Variable incidence tailplanes. (Level 2)
Answers: A. move rapidly when trimming the aircraft during climb.
B. out and landing approach and slowly during cruise always move slowly.

C. move rapidly when trimming the aircraft during the landing approach and slowly at all
other times.

Questions.QuestionString:
73. On an aircraft with a variable incidence trimming tailplane, the tailplane incidence
changes. (Level 2)
Answers: A. if the control column is moved back or forward.
B. automatically if the elevator moves.
C. if the trim wheel is turned back or forward.

Questions.QuestionString:
74. Construction such as horn balance and inset hinge balance installed on control surface
assembly. (Level 2)
Answers: A. serves as a 'servo' system of balance.
B. has same effect of the balance tab.
C. is meant to trim CG of control surfaces.

Questions.QuestionString: 75. Aerodynamic balance. (Level 2)
Answers: B. will cause CP to move towards the trailing edge and cause instability.
C. will cause CP to move towards the trailing edge and cause instability.

Questions.QuestionString:
76. An excess of aerodynamic balance would move the control surface centre of pressure.
(Level 2)
Answers: A. rearwards, resulting in too much assistance.
B. rearwards, resulting in loss of assistance.
C. forwards, resulting in an unstable overbalance.

Questions.QuestionString: 77. A flying control mass balance weight. (Level 2)
Answers: A. keeps the control surface C of G as close to the trailing edge as possible.
B. tends to move the control surface C of G close to the hinge line.
C. ensures that the C of G always acts to aid the pilot thus relieving control column load.

Questions.QuestionString:
78. A bonded waffle doubler, as well as acting as a skin strengthener, also acts as a. (Level
1)
79. The method employed to mass balance control surfaces is to. (Level 2)
Answers: A. attach weights forward of the hinge line.
B. allow the leading edge of the surface to project into the airflow.
C. fit bias strips to the trailing edge of the surfaces.

Questions.QuestionString: 80. A 'frise' aileron is incorporated to. (Level 2)
Answers: A. provide aerodynamic balancing so assisting the pilot to move the control.
B. ensure aileron control is retained at high angles of attack.
C. equalize aileron drag in a turn.

Questions.QuestionString: 81. The balance tab is an auxiliary surface fitted to a main control surface. (Level 2)
Answers: A. operating automatically to provide feel to the controls.
B. operated independently at which point in the length of cable the tensiometer is applied.
C. operating automatically to assist the pilot in moving the controls.

Questions.QuestionString: 82. A flying control mass balance weight. (Level 2)
Answers: A. tends to move the control surface C of G forward of the hinge line.
B. tends to move the control surface C of G close to the hinge line.
C. keeps the control surface C of G as close to the trailing edge as possible.

Questions.QuestionString: 83. Wing mounted podded engines and integral fuel tanks. (Level 2)
Answers: B. provide increased safety if the undercarriage collapses on landing.

Questions.QuestionString: 84. What are the faying surfaces of a repair?. (Level 1)
85. The cabin windows have

86. The vent hole makes sure that during normal operation, the pressure between the
panes is the same as the cabin pressure, it located at?
Answers: A. In the center near the bottom of the inner pane
B. In the center near the top of the inner pane
C. In the center near the bottom of the outer pane

Questions.QuestionString: 87. The nose cap of the leading edge structure is made of
88. The aft pylon attach fittings transmit
Answers: B. Lateral loads and longitudinal loads

Questions.QuestionString: 89. The forward pylon attach fittings transmit
Answers: B. Lateral loads and longitudinal loads

Questions.QuestionString: 90. The tail cone is
91. The movable rudders are attached to
Answers: A. the trailing edge of the fixed vertical stabilizer
B. the leading edge of the fixed vertical stabilizer
C. the center hinge of the fixed vertical stabilizer

Questions.QuestionString: 92. Functions of the wing
Answers: A. Create lift which keeps the aircraft in flight
B. Store fuel for flight and support for the engines
C. Create lift, store fuel for flight and support for the engines

Questions.QuestionString: 93. The wing upper skin panel carries
Answers: A. Mainly tension loads to the fuselage structure
C. Mainly vertical loads to the fuselage structure

Questions.QuestionString: 94. The wing lower skin panel carries
Answers: A. Mainly tension loads to the fuselage structure
B. Mainly compression loads to the fuselage structure
C. Mainly vertical loads to the fuselage structure

Questions.QuestionString: 95. Where is landing gear support arm located?
Answers: C. Wing front spar and wing rear spar

Questions.QuestionString: 96. How many type of aircraft fuselage construction?
97. How far are frames normally spaced used in constructing the fuselage?
98. Where is the keel beam located?
Answers: A. Through the center wing section of the fuselage
B. Through the aft wing section of the fuselage
C. Through the mid section of the fuselage

Questions.QuestionString:
99. In case of emergency, which doors can be used as emergency exit doors for a quick
passenger and crew evacuation ?
100. The basic construction of the doors comprises
Answers: A. The door structure and the different mechanisms
B. The door structure and the linings
C. The door structure, the linings and the different mechanisms

Questions.QuestionString: 101. The door structure consists of
Answers: A. The door frame, beams and intercostals
B. The door frame, beams, formers and intercostals
C. The door frame, formers and intercostals

Questions.QuestionString: 102. The door is supported by
Answers: C. The support arm and the guide arms

Questions.QuestionString: 103. The overhead hatch provides an emergency exit for
Answers: A. The passengers from the cockpit
B. The flight crew from the cockpit
C. The flight crew from the cabin

Questions.QuestionString: 104. To check the reservoir pressure gage?
Answers: A. Check permitted pressures on the pressure-temperature chart
B. Check the yellow band on the reservoir pressure gage
C. Check the green band on the reservoir pressure gage

Questions.QuestionString: 105. When working around or with the reservoir or any mechanism connected to it
Answers: A. You must install the safety caps
B. You must install the safety collars
C. You must install the safety pins

Questions.QuestionString: 106. The bulk cargo door is different from the other cargo doors; it opens?
Answers: A. Inwards and is operated manually
B. Outwards and is operated manually
C. Inwards and is operated electrically

Questions.QuestionString: 107. On Airbus aircraft, a piano hinge connects the cargo door to the fuselage
Answers: A. At the bottom of cargo door
B. At the top of cargo door
C. At the center of cargo door

Questions.QuestionString: 108. The vent door (of cargo door) provides pressure relief by
Answers:
A. Opening outward when the differential pressure between inside and outside of the
fuselage is greater than 1 psi

B. Opening inward when the differential pressure between inside and outside of the fuselage
is greater than 5 psi

C. Opening inward when the differential pressure between inside and outside of the fuselage
is greater than 1 psi

Questions.QuestionString: 109. The aircraft windows are:
Answers: A. The cockpit windows and the observer windows
B. The cockpit windows and the cabin windows
C. The cockpit windows, the cabin windows and the observer windows

Questions.QuestionString: 110. Which windows can be used as flight crew emergency exits
